Award.AwardTitle: STEM Achievement in Baltimore Elementary Schools (SABES)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
STEM Achievement in Baltimore Elementary Schools (SABES), a Partnership between core partners Johns Hopkins University (JHU) and Baltimore City Public Schools (BCPS), works within neighborhoods to build a Community Enterprise for STEM Learning. Supporting Partners include the Greater Homewood Community Corporation, Park Heights Renaissance, Southeast Community Development Corporation, Greektown Community Development Corporation, Education Based Latino Outreach, Child First Authority, Baltimore National Aquarium, and the Maryland Science Center. SABES is a unique approach to STEM education that builds expertise and excitement for STEM learning within target communities by engaging BCPS teachers and students in grades 3-5, caregivers, community-based organizations, afterschool program providers, faculty and students from JHU, members of Baltimore's high-tech businesses, and local museums. SABES not only directly engages approximately forty STEM teachers and more than 1,620 grade 3-5 students at nine elementary schools in three high-minority, low-income, Baltimore neighborhoods, but it extends far into the wider community, drawing on the expertise of higher education faculty at JHU, museums and STEM business leaders. In the process, SABES prepares afterschool STEM project facilitators in each neighborhood, creating a community-wide culture of STEM learning relevant to the lives of its participants in ways that engage caregivers to sustain student curiosity outside of the classroom.

A fundamental premise that undergirds SABES' work is that the integration of science into the learner's world, as opposed to bringing students into the world of scientists, has great potential to enable deep learning, self-efficacy and student agency. Grounded in this perspective, SABES establishes Mutually Beneficial Partnerships (MBPs) in three low-income, majority-minority communities and employs three main strategies to obtain its goals of broad participation in science, increased student achievement in STEM, and increased teacher proficiency. These strategies are: (1) sustained/collaborative professional development including professional learning communities, (2) scaffolds that bridge school learning with applications of STEM in the community including biannual community STEM Recognition Events featuring students' STEM projects, and (3) STEM visiting experts from JHU and high-tech industries as well as field trips linked to careers in action.

The SABES research agenda pursues the following questions: 1. If the impact evaluation shows that some intended outcomes are affected in desired directions by SABES, but others not, what theory-building or holistic understandings of educational improvement efforts and mechanisms can emerge from these findings? 2. What aspects of the proposed intervention are most effective for creating a sustainable STEM community where previously there exists little expertise or organized activity outside the school? 3. How does effectiveness vary between neighborhoods or schools that differ in student composition (e.g., race/ethnicity, and English language proficiency), neighborhood resources and infrastructure, and other aspects of school organization (e.g., other high-priority initiatives in a school that might compete with SABES for staff attention, stability of principal or teacher incumbency)? The research design employs the application of a multi-level, ecological perspective which will result in important findings related to developing science literacy in a community, engagement of formal and informal settings and structures as assets for developing teaching and learning in science, and examining the impacts on achievement, particularly related to closing the achievement gap among students of different ethnicities, language proficiencies and income levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Over six years, SABES engaged over 5,400 students with daily STEM instruction, approximately 500 teachers and school-based leaders in professional development (see Figure 2) and almost 4,300 students, families, and community members at community STEM Showcases.  The SABES multi-dimensional study and program demonstrated how scaffolding the growth of a STEM community extending beyond the classroom and engaging teachers, students and their families in STEM practices that are meaningful in the context of their lives increases STEM literacy in authentic and measureable ways. 

All students had 7% higher gains* from the beginning to the end of the year  in engineering-related problem solving skills in high fidelity SABES schools versus comparison schools (9% improvement vs. 2% improvement).  SABES students show significantly higher interest in science and engineering academic and career pursuits ("I would like to be a scientist", "I would like to be an engineer"), as well as higher confidence in their capacity to succeed ("How sure are you that you can learn science this year?"). 

Though students participating in SABES school day showed higher gains in multiple areas versus comparison schools, the depth and breadth of our work taught us that truly, "it takes a community to raise an engineer."  A multi-layered approach with school day and afterschool (SABES+ in Figure 3) yielded even higher outcomes regarding students' interest, efficacy and abilities in STEM.  Within SABES schools, students who participated in the afterschool program in addition to the school day program showed suggestive evidence of greater engagement in science.  They showed greater confidence in their capacity to succeed relative to their peers in SABES schools (all of whom were more confident than students in the comparison schools [see above]) ("How sure are you that you can learn science this year?").  The students in the after school program also showed greater interest in and affinity for science ("Overall, how interested are you in learning science?", "How much to you like science?").

In addition, ESOL students had 7% higher gains* from the beginning to the end of the year in engineering-related problem solving skills in SABES schools versus comparison schools (9% improvement vs. 2% improvement).  Students receiving special education services had 5% higher gains* on the overall assessment (academic science + engineering) in SABES schools versus comparison schools.  The 2% gain observed among the special education students was not statistically distinguishable from zero; the special education students in SABES schools had a statistically significant gain during the year. 

Overall, SABES showed and reinforced that access to high quality STEM programming for students should be a multi-layered approach (i.e. classroom, afterschool, and/or community) facilitated by well-trained and supported teachers and afterschool facilitators.  It is imperative that in addition to curriculum that staff have access to high quality professional development and instructional support to positively impact teaching practices.

*statistically significant

Broader Impacts

Beyond school, SABES highlights how access to high quality STEM experiences inside and outside of school addresses student equity.  This access helps ensure that students are prepared for and have knowledge of the continued expanding STEM workforce in the Baltimore metropolitan area and beyond.  Project-based STEM pedagogy supports the learning of students who are historically under-served and under-represented in many STEM fields. 

The most important outcome of the work has been the testing of a model for collaborations and partnerships to support and enhance STEM education in public school classrooms.  Through SABES, we have created a mechanism for growing STEM-teacher leaders who enact professional development and serve as mentors to colleagues who engaging students with a high-quality, engaging, inquiry-based curriculum daily.

SABES continues in Baltimore through the District?s development of K-2 curriculum and adoption of the K-5 curriculum for all of their schools for science.  It continues through ongoing STEM Academies for teachers taught by the aforementioned STEM-teacher leaders and it continues through afterschool providers who write SABES afterschool programming into their budgets to provide student driven projects with STEM mentors.  Lastly, the STEM Showcases continue through ongoing partnerships between the university and the district.
